Sorry about that Jim.  What I am referring to are simply the 
messages and =
nothing else (for example this post is a message).  I 
used the word "archi=
ves" because the messages go back from the 
present day all the way to a co=
uple years ago when the group 
started.  So in effect we have a searchable =
archive.

Somewhere around December, the decision was made to let the publi=
c 
be able to see our messages without having to join the group as a 
membe=
r.  Before that, you had to join the group in order to view the 
messages.
=

What I am suggesting is that we go back to the original system, 
where you=
 have to join to see the messages, because being able to 
see them without =
joining essentially discourages joining and hence 
posting.

ken

--- In ne=
at@yahoogroups.com, "Jim O'Flaherty, Jr." 
<jim_oflaherty_jr@...> wrote:

files

recalling

his Yahoo!Group

osed to be

> John Arrowwood wrote:
> 
> > On=
e other possibility is that in December people went on 
vacation (so 
> > t=
o speak), and nobody has really returned yet...  Thus, nobody 
has 
> > sai=
d anything to spark discussion.  I've seen in the past where 
> > something=
 happens (or doesn't happen) and that causes stagnation 
and 
> > quiet.  T=
hen later, the noise level starts to rise again, but 
only 
> > when somebo=
dy actually starts talking about something that 
enough 
> > people are int=
erested in.
> >
> > After all, I'm guessing that people don't join inactive=
 lists, 
so the 
> > fact that the list wasn't very active may be the real =
reason why 
the 
> > new people were so greatly reduced.  Here's an easy wa=
y to find 
out.  
> > Leave the archives public for now.  But find a way to=
 spark 
discussion 
> > that gets all the long-time members engaged.  Get t=
he volume of 
> > messages back up THAT way, and keep it there for a while,=
 and 
see if 
> > new user rate goes up.

> > On 2/22/06=
, *Kenneth Stanley* <kstanley@... 
> > <mailto:kstanley@...>> wrote:
> >
> =
>     Hi Everyone,
> >
> >     I've spoken to Derek James (who runs this gr=
oup) about this 
issue,
> >     and he suggested I bring it up for discussi=
on.  So please 
feel free
> >     to share your thoughts.
> >
> >     I hav=
e come to the conclusion that opening the archives to 
public
> >     viewi=
ng was probably not the best idea in retrospect.  There 
is one
> >     goo=
d motivation for doing so, which is that it makes them
> >     potentially =
searchable from outside engines.  However, on 
balance I
> >     believe it=
 is now apparent after we have run this experiment 
for a
> >     couple mo=
nths that this benefit is outweighed by the 
downsides:
> >
> >     In part=
icular I think opening the archives has significantly
> >     deterred non-=
members from joining the group.  The surface-
level
> >     effect of this =
deterrence is simply that the group grows less
> >     quickly.  However, t=
here is a more concerning secondary 
effect,
> >     which is that when you=
 do not join, you are less likely to 
post even
> >     if you have somethi=
ng worth contributing, because it would 
require
> >     joining to do so. =
 Therefore, the net effect is stagnant 
growth and
> >     a general squelc=
hing of broader discussion and fresh new 
input from
> >     outside.
> >
>=
 >     I also believe there is a more subtle tertiary effect on 
existing
>=
 >     members, which is that now that you don't need to log into 
yahoo to=

> >     view the latest messages, you are more likely not to post 
somethi=
ng
> >     that you think of offhand, because that would require 
logging i=
n.
> >     In the past, since you had to log in in order to view the 
archi=
ves,
> >     you were already logged in once ideas popped into your head, 
=
but now
> >     you are likely not logged in, and therefore it isn't worth =

going to
> >     the trouble just to make a casual point.  I know that I h=
ave 
found
> >     even myself falling into that kind of pattern and not 
p=
osting since
> >     I wasn't logged in.  Again, the net effect is muting 
=
discussion.
> >
> >     The statistics appear to back up this theory.  Of c=
ourse, 
statistics
> >     prove correlation and not causality, but the arg=
ument for 
causality
> >     is strenghened by the precise alignment betwee=
n the time 
that we
> >     opened the archives and the time that membershi=
p growth and 
posting
> >     suddenly plummeted.  Here are the numbers:
> =
>
> >     New Members by Month
> >     --------------------
> >     Oct: 11=

> >     Nov: 14
> >     Dec: 5
> >     Jan: 4
> >     Feb: 3 (so far)
> >
=
> >     New Posts by Month
> >     ------------------
> >     Oct: 76
> >  =
   Nov: 77
> >     Dec: 25
> >     Jan: 38
> >     Feb: 22 (so far)
> >
> >=
     Both statistics show a sudden and dramatic drop right at 
December,
> =
>     right about when we opened the archives.  That seems to 
support the
=
> >     idea that doing so had a negative effect on overall 
participation.=

> >     Of course there are other possible explanations such as the 
natur=
al
> >     ebb and flow of discourse or just a general downward trend 
as p=
eople
> >     change interests, but the coincidental correlation in timing =

makes
> >     it likely that even if those are true, they probably are not=
 
the
> >     only contributing factors.
> >
> >     My view is that this g=
roup is first and foremost a 
discussion group,
> >     and only secondaril=
y a reference site.  It's nice to be able 
to
> >     search for old discus=
ison, but what we're really here for is 
to
> >     interact with each othe=
r in the present.  Therefore, it 
doesn't make
> >     sense to sacrifice t=
he interactive quality for a slightly 
more
> >     convenient reference, a=
t least in my opinion.
> >
> >     So I am recommending we close the archiv=
es to the public 
again and
> >     return to our old system.  However, sin=
ce we have been 
genuinely a
> >     thriving community for several years n=
ow (just look at most 
yahoo
> >     groups and we are almost unmatched in =
consistent quality 
content and
> >     friendly discussion), it is only ri=
ght to let everyone have 
their
> >     two cents before such a decision is=
 made, so we can decide 
together
> >     rather than make a unilateral dec=
ision.  Derek will 
ultimately
> >     decide what to do based on your inpu=
t.  If no one has input, 
it will
> >     just be a decision between myself=
 and Derek, which is fine, 
but this
> >     is your opportunity to partici=
pate.
> >
